I said, ”who put all those things in your head?
 Things that make me feel that I’m mad
 And you’re making me feel like I’ve never been born”

The original line was:
“Who put all that crap in your hair ? and it makes me feel like my trousers are torn”
They ended up softening it and changing the words.



The other person in the conversation opens its mind, only for it to be things that made the narrator openly uncomfortable.

Peter Fonda’s tale of nearly-fatal accidents was this for the Beatles, with John replying “Listen mate, shut up about that stuff” and an eventual part of the lyrics: “You’re making me feel like I’ve never been born.” George Harrison added that “He was showing us his bullet wound. He was very uncool.”

She said, ”I know what it’s like to be dead
 I know what it is to be sad
 I know what it’s like to be dead”

Inspired by an acid trip, it recounts a bad trip for George Harrison. Actor Peter Fonda arrived, also tripping, and tried to comfort the frightened Harrison, who thought he was dying.

I told him there was nothing to be afraid of and that all he needed to do was relax. I said that I knew what it was like to be dead because when I was 10 years old I’d accidentally shot myself in the stomach and my heart stopped beating three times while I was on the operating table because I’d lost so much blood.
John was passing at the time and heard me saying ‘I know what it’s like to be dead’. He looked at me and said, ‘You’re making me feel like I’ve never been born. Who put all that shit in your head?’
-Peter Fonda

When I was a boy everything was right
 Everything was right

This was originally planned to be a song of its own, but Lennon could not finish it, so George Harrison suggested he fit it into this one.

He had loads of bits, maybe three songs, that were unfinished, and I made suggestions and helped him to work them together so that they became one finished song, She Said She Said. The middle part of that record is a different song.

She said, ”I know what it’s like to be dead
 I know what it is to be sad”
 And she’s making me feel like I’ve never been born

The lyrics stem from an LSD-fueled party with Peter Fonda that the Beatles attended in the 1960s. Fonda was remembering a self-inflicted gunshot wound in his youth that nearly killed him, knowing the feeling of death. Fonda quipped the famous line, “I know what it’s like to be dead.”



The Beatles took the memory to song, using the dark imagery to play out a relationship fight. Arguing, the two drive each other to feel like death is near, each pushing the buttons to make the other feel more sad than before.
